A large group of people from the village of Holly protested and destroyed property of another villager over disagreements on land rights.

Following the death of a farmer at the hands of a herder in the Kantchari area, other farmers organized a manhunt to hunt the culprit and burn the houses of farmers in the area. Police intervened to limit the damage.
A Hausa farmer was killed by a herder after a dispute related to livestock moving through the farmer's fields in Kantchari.
The national road in Bobo-Dioulasso was closed by demonstrators demanding the return of money seized by police in the area.
Agricultural workers staged a sit-in at the regional office of Zondoma in Titao in favour of their demands.
Clashes between protesters and police were reported in Ouahigouya after the trial of a man who was being tried for contempt of court and insulting a judge.

Protesters armed with rduimentary weapons in Boussouma attempted to attack the deputy mayor but were stopped by the visiting Prime Minister's security forces. The cause of the actions of the protesters was not clear.

Protesters in Ouahigouya forcibly released a prisoner from a prison in the town. The person was arrested for allegedly insulting a magistrate. Security forces were present but the protesters overwhelmed them.
Cattle traders protested in Pouytenga and marched over the relocation of their market.
Teachers staged a sit-in in front of the Ministries of Education and Secondary/Higher Education in Ouagadougou in favour of their grievances.
Residents of Sector 30 in Ouagadougou protested and blocked the city's ring road over the accidental shooting of a young girl by soldiers in the area.

A local mayor attempting to get some people illegally occupying the Blaise Compaore National Hospital in Tengadogo was chased out by the angry residents who threw stones at his vehicle as he left the area.

Taxi drivers attempted to march on a police station in the Bogodogo area of Ouagadougou following a road accident where a taxi driver was arrested. Police used tear gas to disperse the demonstrators and arrested at least 11, as well as impounding as many as 85 taxis.

Ethnic rivals battle in an area south of Ouagadougou. The rivalry culminated when the son of the Akonga chief was killed by the Liliou group. The Akonga sought revenge, killing nine members of the rival community.

Residents of Bobo-Dioulasso, including many students, violently protested after police killed a man during an arrest. At least 4 cars and 2 motorcycles of the governorate were burned by the protesters.
Students in Koudougou staged a 48-hour strike in memory of students who died in violence last year. They marked the beginning of the strike with a peace march.
After the car of the minister of justice narrowly avoided hitting a pedestrian, his bodyguards allegedly beat up the man. The justice minister was later fired over the incident.

actor1: MNLA: National Movement for the Liberation of Azawad

Workers of the National Blood Transfusion Center (CNTS) observed a 48-hour sit-in in Ouagadougou in favour of their demands.

A clash was reported between farmers in Bombore and Fulani herders in the Mogtedo municipality. A Fulani herder was hit in the head by a machete during the incident before other Fulani drove off Bombore attackers. The cause of the incident was allegedly some livestock crossing a farmers field.
Clashes between police and rioters at a mine in Pelegtanga left several people injured.

Hundreds of Ministry of Economy and Finance employees protested to demand equality in the distribution of pooled funds.

After a policeman shot a mechanic, citizens responded by burning and ransacking the police station. A curfew was imposed in the town by military officers to try and keep peace in the town.
Riots broke out in Banfora after a police officer shot a man in custody. Rioters ransacked the police station. Soldiers responded to the rioters and imposed a curfew on the town.
Soldiers protested peacefully to demand a wage increase.
Civil servant workers protested low wages and human rights abuses by the government. The day was chosen for protesting since it was the second day of a five day conference of Islamic countries.
Rioters burned down the homes of ruling party members over the death of journalist, Norbert Zongo. Police intervened and arrested leading opposition party members.
Riots broke out which resulted in the burning of homes belonging to ruling party members. Two opposition leaders were detained for inciting the riots.
Students rioted for the arrest of six Presidential Guard accused of killing journalist Norbert Zongo by setting up barricades of burning tires. Police fired teargas into the crowd of rioters.
Police fired teargas at protesters demonstrating for an investigation into Norbert Zongos death.

Students rioted for the arrest of six Presidential Guard accused of killing journalist Norbert Zongo by setting up barricades of burning tires and smashing car windows. Police fired teargas into the crowd of rioters.
Protesters demonstrated against government impunity.
Protesters demonstrated for further investigations into the death of Norbert Zongo, a journalist.
Opposition parties held a protest over political grievances- one being the death of Norbert Zongo.

actor1: CDP: Congress for Democracy and Progress
notes: Clashes broke out between members of the Congress for Democracy and Progress and opposition militants over a cross country race. The opposition group thought the race was disrespectful to the deceased journalist, Norbert Zongo. Two people were wounded

actor2: CDP: Congress for Democracy and Progress
notes: Opposition militants fought members of the Congress for Democracy and Progress ruling party. Two people were wounded.
A peaceful protest was held in memory of deceased journalist, Norbert Zongo.
Power workers went on strike and turned off the electricity to protest the killing of power company worker, Auguste Ouedraogo.
A SONABEL power worker, Auguste Ouedraogo, was tortured and killed police.
Three members of the military beat to death an electrician worker.
Opposition political groups held protests over the death of Norbert Zongo.
Over 3,000 people demonstrated for further investigations into the death of Norbert Zongo, a journalist.
Over 3,000 people demonstrated for further investigations into the death of Norbert Zongo, a journalist.
Opposition political groups held protests over the death of Norbert Zongo.
Demonstrators protested against the killing of journalist, Norbert Zongo. Police responded by firing into the crowd. Four people were shot by police.
Police fired teargas at protesters demonstrating for an investigation into Norbert Zongos death. Zongo was an outspoken journalist killed in 12/98 in Burkina Faso.
In the hometown of journalist Norbert Zongo, who was killed in 12/98, riots broke out. Rioters torched buildings and cars. Police responded.
Protesters demonstrated for an investigation into the death of Norbert Zongo, an outspoken journalist who was killed earlier in the month.
Students protested over circumstances surrounding the death of outspoken jounralist, Norbert Zongo.
Norbert Zongo, an outspoken journalist against the government, and three other people were killed by an unidentified armed group. The killings are suspected to be political.
Police fired teargas at student protesters demanding better university provisions.
Police fired teargas at students protesting for the release of two student leaders who were arrested the previous week.
Police fired teargas at protesters demonstrating for the release of two student leaders.
Students demontrated for the release of two students who were arrested the previous week. To break up the demonstration, police fired teargas into the crowd.
